t: “Do*pn you think this is just? You*ld say, ‘I am in the right, not God.’
Yet*ln you ask him, ‘What profit is it to me, and*ld what do I gain by not sinning?’
“I*pn would like to reply to you and*ld to your friends with you.
Look*ln up at the heavens and see; gaze*ld at the clouds so high above you.
If*ln you sin, how does that affect him? If*ld your sins are many, what does that do to him?
If*ln you are righteous, what do you give to him, or*ld what does he receive from your hand?
Your*ln wickedness only affects humans like yourself, and*ld your righteousness only other people.
“People*pn cry out under a load of oppression; they*ld plead for relief from the arm of the powerful.
But*ln no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker, who*ld gives songs in the night,
who*ln teaches us more than he teaches the beasts of the earth and*ld makes us wiser than the birds in the sky?’
He*ln does not answer when people cry out because*ld of the arrogance of the wicked.
Indeed,*ln God does not listen to their empty plea; the*ld Almighty pays no attention to it.
How*ln much less, then, will he listen when*ld you say that you do not see him, that*ln your case is before him and*ld you must wait for him,
and*ln further, that his anger never punishes and*ld he does not take the least notice of wickedness.
So*ln Job opens his mouth with empty talk; without*ld knowledge he multiplies words.”
